key_insight: ReaSeq enriches sequential recommender models by injecting world knowledge through a reasoning layer, turning brittle ID-only item representations into semantically informed embeddings and enabling capture of beyond-log user interests.
problem_solved: Addresses two industrial limitations: sparse, ID-based item representations that hurt interest modeling under data sparsity, and the inability to reason about user interests outside platform logs.
method: Augment item IDs with external world knowledge (product semantics, attributes, text) to create richer representations.
Apply a reasoning module that propagates and refines knowledge along user interaction sequences to reveal latent interests beyond logs.
Train the sequential model with objectives that align sequence prediction and knowledge-consistency to improve robustness under sparsity.
impact: Provides a practical path for recommender systems to become more robust to cold-start and limited logs by leveraging external knowledge; practitioners can boost sequence modeling performance and capture cross-platform or latent interests without relying solely on interaction counts.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: external knowledge retrieval → reasoning module → enriched item embeddings → sequential model
Before/after illustration: ID-only sparse embedding vs. semantically enriched embedding showing improved interest coverage

paper_title: ReaSeq: Unleashing World Knowledge via Reasoning for Sequential Modeling
paper_authors: Chuan Wang, Gaoming Yang, Han Wu, Jiakai Tang, Jiahao Yu
